[[Allahabad]], [[India]] | mouth_coordinates = {{coord|25|25|11.44|N|81|53|5.80|E|display=inline,title}} | mouth_elevation = {{convert|74|m|abbr=on}} | progression = | river_system = | basin_size = {{convert|366223|km2|abbr=on}} | tributaries_left = [[Hindon River|Hindon]], [[Kali River (Uttarakhand)|Sharda]], [[Giri River|Giri]], Rishiganga, Hanuman Ganga, [[Sasur Khaderi]] | tributaries_right = [[Chambal River|Chambal]], [[Betwa River|Betwa]], [[Ken River|Ken]], [[Sindh River|Sindh]], [[Tons River|Tons]] | custom_label = | custom_data = | extra = }} <!-- [[File:YamunaRiver.jpg|thumb|River Yamuna near [[Agra]]]] THIS IMAGE IS ACTUALLY by the Taj at AGRA, and we already have another image below-->
The '''Yamuna''' ([[Hindustani language|Hindustani]]: {{IPA-hi|jəmʊnaː|pron}}), also known as the '''Jumna''' or '''Jamuna''' (not to be mistaken with the [[Jamuna River (Bangladesh)|Jamuna]] of [[Bangladesh]]), is the second largest [[tributary]] [[river]] of the [[Ganges]] (Ganga) and the longest tributary in [[Rivers of India|India]]. Originating from the [[Yamunotri]] Glacier at a height of {{convert|6387|m}} on the southwestern slopes of [[Bandarpunch| Banderpooch]] peaks of the [[Lower Himalayan Range|Lower Himalaya]] in [[Uttarakhand]], it travels a total length of {{convert|1376|km|mi}} and has a [[Drainage system (Geomorphology) |drainage system]] of {{convert|366223|km2|mi2}}, 40.2% of the entire [[Ganges Basin]]. It merges with the Ganges at [[Triveni Sangam]], [[Allahabad]], which is a site of the [[Kumbha Mela|Kumbh Mela]], a Hindu festival held every 12 years.
It crosses several states: [[Haryana]] and [[Uttar Pradesh]], passing by [[Uttarakhand]] and later [[Delhi]], and meeting its tributaries on the way, including [[Tons River|Tons]], its largest tributary, [[Chambal River|Chambal]], its longest tributary which has its own large basin, followed by [[Sindh River|Sindh]], the [[Betwa]], and [[Ken River|Ken]]. The Yamuna does not pass across [[Himachal Pradesh]], but receives water from that state via the Tons. It helps create the highly fertile [[Alluvium|alluvial]] Yamuna-Ganges [[Doab]] region between itself and the Ganges in the [[Indo-Gangetic plain]]. Nearly 57 million people depend on the Yamuna's waters. With an annual flow of about 10,000 cubic billion metres (cbm; 8.1 billion acre⋅ft) and usage of 4,400 cbm (of which irrigation constitutes 96 per cent), the river accounts for more than 70 per cent of Delhi's water supply. Like the Ganges, the Yamuna is highly venerated in [[Hinduism]] and worshipped as the goddess Yamuna. In [[Hindu mythology]] she is the daughter of the Sun God, [[Surya]], and the sister of [[Yama]], the God of Death, hence also known as [[Yami]]. According to popular legends, bathing in its sacred waters frees one from the torments of death.<ref name=hy>{{cite book |title= Hydrology and water resources of India—Volume 57 of Water science and technology library |last= Jain |first= Sharad K.|authorlink= |author2= Pushpendra K. Agarwal |author3= Vijay P. Singh |year= 2007|publisher= Springer|location= |isbn= 1-4020-5179-4|pages= 344–354 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZKs1gBhJSWIC&pg=RA1-PA345&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna%20River&f=false |ref= }}</ref><ref name=brit>{{cite book |title= Students' Britannica India, Volumes 1-5 |last= Hoiberg |first= Dale|authorlink= |year= 2000|publisher= Popular Prakashan|location= |isbn= 0-85229-760-2|pages= 290–291|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=DPP7O3nb3g0C&pg=PA290&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna%20River&f=false |ref= }}</ref>
At the [[Hathni Kund Barrage]], its waters are diverted into two large canals: the Western Yamuna Canal flowing towards Haryana and the Eastern Yamuna Canal towards Uttar Pradesh. Beyond that point the Yamuna is joined only by the [[Somb]], a seasonal rivulet from Haryana, and by the highly polluted [[Hindon River]] near Noida, so that it continues only as a trickling sewage-bearing drain before joining the [[Chambal River| Chambal]] at [[Pachnada]] in the [[Etawah District]] of Uttar Pradesh.<ref name=nowater1>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2007/20071118/spectrum/main1.htm And filthy flows the Yamuna], [[The Tribune (Chandigarh) |The Tribune]], 18 Nov 2007.</ref> The water of Yamuna is of "reasonably good quality" through its length from Yamunotri in the Himalayas to [[Wazirabad barrage]] in Delhi, about {{convert|375|km|mi}}; below this, the discharge of wastewater through 15 drains between Wazirabad barrage and Okhla barrage renders the river severely polluted.
One official described the river as a "sewage drain" with [[biochemical oxygen demand]] (BOD) values ranging from 14 to 28 mg/l and high [[coliform]] content.<ref>{{cite web |title= 'Ganga is the most polluted river' |url= http://www.hinduonnet.com/2003/11/23/stories/2003112300531100.htm |date= Nov 23, 2003 |publisher= [[The Hindu]] |page= |access-date= 12 February 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080915043255/http://www.hinduonnet.com/2003/11/23/stories/2003112300531100.htm |archive-date= 15 September 2008 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> There are three main sources of pollution in the river: household and municipal disposal sites, soil erosion resulting from deforestation occurring to make way for agriculture, and resulting chemical wash-off from fertilizers, herbicides, and pesticides and run-off from commercial activity and industrial sites. The Yamuna from its origin at [[Yamunotri]] to Okhla barrage is called the Upper Yamuna.<ref name="okhla5"> 2015, [https://books.google.com.sg/books?isbn=8123020066 INDIA 2015], New Media Wing. </ref>
==Basin== [[File:Himalayas at dusk from Mussoorie, Uttarakhand.jpg|left|300px|thumb|Banderpoonch peak, the source of Yamuna, as seen from [[Mussoorie]]]] [[File:Yamunotri temple and ashram.jpg|left|180px|thumb|The [[Yamunotri]] temple on the river, dedicated to Goddess Yamuna]][[File:DoabUnitedProvincesIGI1908.jpg|right|290px|thumb|The [[Doab]], [[United Provinces of Agra and Oudh|United Provinces]], 1908]]
===Palaeochannels=== The present [[Sarsuti]] river which originates in the Shivalik hills in [[Himachal]] and [[Haryana]] border and merges with [[Ghaggar-Hakra River|Ghaggar River]] near [[Pehowa]] is the [[palaeochannel]] of Yamuna.<ref name=sarsuti1>[http://cgwb.gov.in/Ground-Water/Final%20print%20version_Palaeochannel%20Expert%20Committee_15thOct2016.pdf PALAEOCHANNELS OF NORTH WEST INDIA], Central Ground Water Board, last page of prefce.</ref> Yamuna changed its course to the east due to a shift in the slope of the [[Continental crust|earth's crust]] caused by [[plate tectonics]].<ref name=sarsuti1/>
===Source=== The source of Yamuna lies in the [[Yamunotri]] Glacier at an elevation of {{convert|6387|m|ft}}, on the south-western slopes of Banderpooch peaks, which lie in the [[Mussoorie]] range of the [[Lower Himalayan Range|Lower Himalayas]], north of [[Haridwar]] in [[Uttarkashi district]], [[Uttarakhand]].<ref name=hy/> Yamunotri temple, a shrine dedicated to the goddess Yamuna, is one of the holiest shrines in [[Hinduism]], and part of the [[Chota Char Dham]] [[Yatra]] circuit. Also standing close to the temple, on its {{convert|13|km|mi|0|adj=on}} trek route that follows the right bank of the river, lies Markendeya Tirtha, where the sage [[Markandeya]] wrote the [[Markandeya Purana]].<ref name=utt>[http://uttarkashi.nic.in/aboutDistt/Temple.htm Yamunotri Temple] [[Uttarkashi district]] website. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731232226/http://uttarkashi.nic.in/aboutDistt/Temple.htm |date=31 July 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The holy Himalaya: a geographical interpretation of Garhwal - Yamuna Drainage System|last=Nand|first=Nitya |authorlink= |author2=Kamlesh Kumar |year=1989|publisher=Daya Books|location= |isbn=81-7035-055-7|page=49 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wmNGKpcE83cC&pg=PA49&dq=Yamuna#v=onepage&q=Yamuna&f=false |ref= }}</ref>
===Current course=== From Markendeya Tirtha, the river flows southwards for about {{convert|200|km|mi}}, through the Lower Himalayas and the [[Shivalik Hills]] Range. [[Morainic]] deposits are found along the steep Upper Yamuna, highlighted with [[geomorphic]] features such as [[interlocking spur]]s, steep rock [[Bench (geology)|benches]], gorges and [[stream terrace]]s. Large terraces formed over a long period of time can be seen in the lower course of the river, such as those near Naugoan. An important part of its early [[Water catchment area|catchment area]], totalling {{convert|2320|km2|mi2}}, lies in [[Himachal Pradesh]]. The [[Tons River|Tons]], Yamana's largest tribuary, drains a large portion of the upper catchment area and holds more water than the main stream. It rises from the Hari-ki-dun valley and merges after Kalsi near [[Dehradun]]. The drainage system of the river stretches between Giri-[[Sutlej]] catchment in Himachal and Yamuna-[[Bhilangna]] catchment in [[Garhwal division|Garhwal]], also draining the ridge of [[Shimla]]. [[Kalanag]] ({{convert|6387|m|ft|disp=sqbr}}) is the highest point of the Yamuna basin. Other tributaries in the region are the Giri, Rishi Ganga, Kunta, Hanuman Ganga and Bata, which drain the upper catchment area of the Yamuna basin.<ref>[http://www.webindia123.com/himachal/land/rivers.htm#R General outline of rivers in Himachal @ webindia123]</ref> [[File:Chandigarh river.jpg|thumb|Yamuna river between [[Saharanpur]] and Yamunanagar]] From the upper catchment area, the river descends onto the plains of [[Doon Valley]], at [[Dak Pathar]] near Dehradun. Flowing through the [[Dakpathar Barrage]], the water is diverted into a canal for power generation. Further downstream, the Assan River joins the Yamuna at the [[Asan Barrage]], which hosts a bird sanctuary. After passing the [[Sikh]] pilgrimage town of [[Paonta Sahib]], the Yamuna reaches [[Tajewala]] in [[Yamuna Nagar district]] (named after the river) of [[Haryana]]. A dam built here in 1873 is the origin of two important canals, the Western and Eastern [[Yamuna Canal]]s, which irrigate the states of Haryana and Uttar Pradesh. The Western Yamuna Canal (WYC) crosses [[Yamuna Nagar]], [[Karnal]] and [[Panipat]] before reaching the Haiderpur treatment plant, which contributes to [[Delhi]]'s municipal water supply. The Yamuna receives wastewater from Yamuna Nagar and Panipat cities; beyond this it is replenished by seasonal streams and groundwater [[accrual]]. During the dry season, the Yamuna remains dry in many stretches between the Tajewala dam and Delhi, where it enters near the [[Palla barrage]] after traversing {{convert|224|km|mi}}.
The Yamuna defines the state borders between Himachal Pradesh and Uttarakhand, and between Haryana, Delhi and [[Uttar Pradesh]]. When the Yamuna reaches the [[Indo-Gangetic plain]], it runs almost parallel to the Ganges, the two rivers creating the Ganges-Yamuna [[Doab]] region. Spread across {{convert|69000|km2|mi2}}, one-third of the [[alluvial]] plain, the region is known for its agricultural output, particularly for the cultivation of [[basmati]] rice. The plain's agriculture supports one-third of India's population.<ref>{{cite book |title=Archaeology of Lower Ganga-Yamuna Doab (circa 1200 B.C. to 1200 A.D.)|last=Sharma|first=Deo Prakash |authorlink= |year=2006|publisher=Bharatiya Kala Prakashan|location= |isbn=81-8090-033-9 |pages=10, 214 |url= |ref= |quote="[[Doab]] is a [[Persian language|Persian]] word, from ''Do-Ab'', literally meaning 'two rivers', or land between two rivers".}}</ref> [[File:Indo-Gangetic Plain.jpg|right|200px|thumb|Course of Yamuna, in the [[Indo-Gangetic Plain]]]]
{| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" |+ |- ! State ! Catchment area (km<sup>2</sup>) ! % of catchment area |- |[[Uttar Pradesh]] and [[Uttarakhand]] |74,208 |21.5 |- |[[Himachal Pradesh]] |5,799 |1.6 |- |[[Haryana]] |21,265 |6.5 |- |[[Rajasthan]] |102,883 |29.8 |- |[[Madhya Pradesh]] |140,230 |40.6 |- |[[Delhi]] |1,485 |0.4 |}
Subsequently, the Yamana flows through the states of Delhi, Haryana and Uttar Pradesh] before merging with the [[Ganges]] at a sacred spot known as [[Triveni Sangam]] in [[Allahabad]]. Pilgrims travel by boats to platforms erected in midstream to offer prayers. During the [[Kumbh Mela]], held every 12 years, large congregations of people immerse themselves in the sacred waters of the confluence.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,798222,00.html At the Three Rivers] ''[[TIME]]'', February 23, 1948.</ref> The cities of [[Baghpat]], Delhi, [[Noida]], [[Mathura, Uttar Pradesh|Mathura]], [[Agra]], [[Firozabad]], [[Etawah]], [[Kalpi]], [[Hamirpur district, Uttar Pradesh|Hamirpur]], and Allahabad lie on its banks. At Etawah, it meets it another important tributary, [[Chambal River|Chambal]], followed by a host of [[tributaries]] further down, including, Sindh, the [[Betwa]], and [[Ken River|Ken]].<ref name=brit/><ref>[http://www.rainwaterharvesting.org/crisis/River-yamuna.htm State of River Yamuna]</ref>
===Important tributaries=== [[File:Jamuna_catchment.jpg|thumb|Catchment boundary of the Yamuna]] Along its {{convert|1376|km|mi|adj=on}} length, the Yamuna has many notable tributaries: * [[Tons River]], Yamuna's largest tributary,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.am/books?id=ZKs1gBhJSWIC&pg=PA349&dq=Tons+River,+Yamuna%27s+largest+tributary#v=onepage&q=Tons%20River%2C%20Yamuna's%20largest%20tributary&f=false|title=Hydrology and Water Resources of India Volume 57 of Water Science and Technology Library|last1=Sharad K.|first1= Jain|last2=Pushpendra K.|first2= Agarwal|last3= Vijay P.|first3= Singh|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media, 2007|page=349}}</ref> which rises in the {{convert|6315|m|ft|adj=mid|-high}} Bandarpoonch mountain, and has a large basin in [[Himachal Pradesh]]. It meets Yamuna below Kalsi near [[Dehradun]], Uttarakhand. * [[Hindon River]], which originates in the [[Saharanpur District]], from Upper [[Siwalik Hills|Shivalik]] in the [[Lower Himalayan Range]]. It is entirely rainfed and has a [[drainage basin|catchment area]] of {{convert|7083|km2|mi2}}, traverses {{convert|400|km|mi}} through [[Muzaffarnagar District]], [[Meerut District]], [[Baghpat District]], [[Ghaziabad, India|Ghaziabad]], [[Noida]] and [[Greater Noida]], before joining Yamuna just outside [[Delhi]]. * [[Ken River]], which flows through the [[Bundelkhand]] region of [[Madhya Pradesh]] and Uttar Pradesh. It originates near Ahirgawan village in [[Jabalpur district]] and travels a distance of {{convert|427|km|mi}} before merging with the Yamuna at Chilla village, near [[Fatehpur, Fatehpur|Fatehpur]] in Uttar Pradesh. It has an overall [[drainage basin]] of {{convert|28058|km2|mi2}}. * [[Chambal River]], known as Charmanvati in ancient texts, which is Yamuna's longest tributary. It flows through Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh and traverses a total distance of {{convert|960|km|mi}} from its source in [[Vindhya Range]], near [[Mhow]]. With a drainage basin of {{convert|143219|km2|mi2}}, it supports hydro-power generation at [[Gandhi Sagar dam]], [[Rana Pratap Sagar dam]] and Jawahar Sagar dam, before merging into the Yamuna south east of Sohan Goan, in [[Etawah district]]. * [[Sindh River]], which joins the Yamuna shortly after the Chambal. * [[Sasur Khaderi River]], {{a.k.a.}} Sasur Khaderi, which is a tributary in [[Fatehpur district|Fatehpur]] district.
=={{anchor|Ancient literature and history}}History== [[File:Krishna carried over river yamuna.jpg|right|220px|thumb|[[Vasudeva|Vasudev]] carrying baby Lord [[Krishna]] across the Yamuna, an important legend of [[Bhagavata Purana]].]]
The name ''Yamuna'' seems to be derived from the [[Sanskrit]] word "yama", meaning 'twin', and it may have been applied to the river because it runs parallel to the Ganges. The Yamuna is mentioned at many places in the [[Rig Veda]], which was composed during the [[Vedic period]] {{circa|1700–1100}} CE, and also in the later [[Atharvaveda]], and the [[Brahmana]]s including [[Aitareya Brahmana]] and [[Shatapatha Brahmana]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Vedic Index of Names and Subjects (V-208-1333-2|page=186|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U5GaKHfNzScC&pg=PA186&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna%20River&f=false|ref= }}</ref> In the [[Rigveda]], the story of the Yamuna describes her "excessive love" for her twin, [[Yama]], who in turn asks her to find a suitable match for herself, which she does in [[Krishna]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.am/books?id=oAHhdczi9CcC&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq=story+of+the+Yamuna+describes+her+%22excessive+love%22+for+her+twin,+Yama,&source=bl&ots=S2odOiJc-9&sig=XzuRSWcjTvwPUoMFao6oJcNqoCU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiauPa_u-DdAhXjsYsKHW9uBDEQ6AEwAXoECAcQAQ#v=onepage&q=story%20of%20the%20Yamuna%20describes%20her%20%22excessive%20love%22%20for%20her%20twin%2C%20Yama%2C&f=false|title=Troubled Waters: Religion, Ethics, and the Global Water Crisis|last=Gary|first= Chamberlain|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield, 2008|page=18|}}</ref>
The tale is further detailed in the 16th century [[Sanskrit]] hymn, ''Yamunashtakam'', an ode by the philosopher [[Vallabhacharya]]. Here the story of her descent to meet her beloved Krishna and to purify the world has been put into verse. The hymn also praises her for being the source of all spiritual abilities. And while the Ganges is considered an epitome of asceticism and higher knowledge and can grant ''[[Moksha]]'' or [[liberty|liberation]], it is Yamuna, who, being a holder of infinite love and compassion, can grant freedom, even from death, the realm of her elder brother. Vallabhacharya writes that she rushes down the Kalinda Mountain, and describes her as the daughter of Kalinda, giving her the name ''Kalindi'', the backdrop of Krishna Leela. The text also talks about her water being of the colour of Lord Krishna, which is dark (Shyam).<ref>{{cite book |title= Earth democracy: justice, sustainability and peace-G - Reference, Information and Interdisciplinary Subjects Series |last=Shiva|first= Vandana |authorlink=Vandana Shiva |year=2006|publisher=Zed Books|location= |isbn=1-84277-777-7|pages=172–173 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iQzwwzBYGDkC&pg=PA172&dq=Yamuna#v=onepage&q=Yamuna&f=false |ref= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Troubled waters: religion, ethics, and the global water crisis |last=Chamberlain|first=Gary|authorlink= |year=2008|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=0-7425-5245-4|page=18|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=oAHhdczi9CcC&pg=PA16&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna%20River&f=false|ref= }}</ref> The river is referred to as Asita in some historical texts.<ref>{{cite book|title=India through the ages|last=Gopal|first=Madan|year= 1990| page= 72|editor=K.S. Gautam|publisher=Publication Division, Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, Government of India}}</ref>
It is mentioned as [[Iomanes]] ([[Ioames]]) in the surveys of [[Seleucus I Nicator]], an officer of [[Alexander the Great]] and one of the [[Diadochi]], who visited India in 305 BCE. Greek traveller and geographer [[Megasthenes]] visited India sometime before 288 BCE (the date of [[Chandragupta Maurya|Chandragupta]]'s death) and mentioned the river in his ''[[Indica (Megasthenes)|Indica]]'', where he described the region around it as the land of Surasena.<ref>{{cite book |title=Megasthenes and Indian Religion- Volume 11 of History and Culture Series |last=Dahlaquist |first=Allan |authorlink= |year=1996|publisher=[[Motilal Banarsidass]] Publ.|location= |isbn=81-208-1323-5|page=386 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xp35-8gTRDkC&pg=PA130&dq=Yamuna#v=onepage&q=Yamuna&f=false |ref= }}</ref> In ''[[Mahabharata]]'', the [[Pandava]] capital of [[Indraprastha]] was situated on the banks of Yamuna, considered to be the site of modern Delhi.
Geological evidence indicates that in the distant past the Yamuna was a tributary of the [[Ghaggar River]] (also known as the [[Vedic Sarasvati River]]), but that it later changed its course eastward due to a [[tectonic]] event, becoming a tributary of the Ganges. This may have led to the Sarasvati River drying up, the end of many [[Harappan civilisation]] settlements, and creation of the [[Thar desert]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of Indian Archaeology |last=Ghosh |first=A. |authorlink= |year=1991|publisher=BRILL |location= |isbn=90-04-09264-1|page= 214 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wba-EZhZcfgC&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=yamuna+ghaggar+tributary |ref= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=In Search of the Cradle of Civilization |last=Feuerstein |first=Georg |authorlink= |author2=Subhash Kak |author3=David Frawley |year=2001|publisher=Quest Books|location= |isbn=0-8356-0741-0 |page=89 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ermk_FmwcS4C&pg=PA89&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna&f=false |ref= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Gods, Sages and Kings: Vedic Secrets of Ancient Civilization|last=Frawley|first=David |authorlink=David Frawley |year=2000|publisher=Lotus Press|location= |isbn=0-910261-37-7|page=95|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=DM58BhuR2KwC&pg=PA108&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna&f=false|ref= }}</ref> However, recent geological research suggests that the diversion of the Yamuna to the Ganges may have occurred during the [[Pleistocene]], and thus could not be connected to the decline of the Harappan civilisation in the region.<ref>Clift et al. 2012. "U-Pb zircon dating evidence for a Pleistocene Sarasvati River and capture of the Yamuna River." Geology, v. 40. [http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/early/2012/01/23/G32840.1.abstract]</ref>
Most of the great empires which ruled over a majority of India were based in the highly fertile Ganges–Yamuna basin, including the [[Magadha]] ({{circa|600 BCE}}), [[Maurya Empire]] (321–185 BCE), [[Shunga Empire]] (185–73 BCE), [[Kushan Empire]] (1st–3rd centuries CE), and [[Gupta Empire]] (280–550 CE), and many had their capitals here, in cities like [[Pataliputra]] or [[Mathura]]. These rivers were revered throughout these kingdoms that flourished on their banks; since the period of [[Chandragupta II]] ({{abbr|r.|reigned}} 375–415 CE), statues both the Ganges and Yamuna became common throughout the Gupta Empire. Further to the South, images of the Ganges and Yamuna are found amidst shrines of the Chalukyas, [[Rashtrakutas]] (753–982), and on their royal seals; prior to them, the [[Chola Empire]] also added the river into their architectural motifs. The Three River Goddess shrine, next to the Kailash rock-cut Temple at [[Ellora Caves|Ellora]], shows the Ganges flanked by the Yamuna and Saraswati.<ref>{{cite book |title=Lives of Indian images |last=Davis|first=Richard H. |authorlink= |year=1999|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=0-691-00520-6|pages=74–76|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=5OGFrDcLbogC&pg=PA75&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna%20River&f=false |ref= }}</ref>
==Religious significance== {{main|Yamuna in Hinduism}} [[File:Yamuna, personificazione del fiume sacro yamuna, IX sec.JPG|right|thumb|The goddess Yamuna]]
The goddess of the river, also known as Yami, is the sister of [[Yama (Hinduism)|Yama]], the god of [[death]], and the daughter of [[Surya]], the [[Sun god]], and his wife [[Saranyu]].<ref>[[Bhagavata Purana]] 8.13.9</ref> Yamuna, referred to respectfully as Yamunaji, holds a very important position in [[Pushtimarg|Pushti Marga]], a large sect of Hinduism based on the [[Shuddhadvaita|ShuddhAdvaita]], in which [[Krishna|Shri Krishna]] is the main deity, propagated by [[Vallabhacharya|VallabhAcharya / MahaPrabhuji]].
The river Yamuna is connected to the religious beliefs surrounding [[Krishna]] and various stories of the two are found in [[Hindu religious texts]], especially the [[Puranas]]. One such story is ''Kaliya Daman'' about the subduing of [[Kaliya]], a ''[[Naga (mythology)|Nāga]]'' which had inhabited the river and terrorised the people of [[Braja]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Classical Hindu mythology: a reader in the Sanskrit Purānas |last=Dimmitt|first=Cornelia|authorlink= |year=1978|publisher=Temple University Press|location= |isbn=0-87722-122-7 |page=329 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TmFOX7q2IqgC&pg=PA329&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna%20River&f=false |ref= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.celextel.org/stotrasother/yamunashtakam.html Yamunashtakam Text and Translation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100625023157/http://www.celextel.org/stotrasother/yamunashtakam.html |date=25 June 2010 }}</ref> Yamuna, according to the legends, is closely related to Lord Krishna and Mahabharata. Krishna was taken across the Yamuna on the night of his birth. Krishna's maternal uncle [[Kamsa|Kansa]] had planned to kill all his nephews, as his eighth nephew was predicted to be his [[Kāla (time)|Kāla]]. When [[Vasudeva]], carrying Krishna in a basket, reached the river Yamuna, on the stormy night of Krishna's birth, Yamuna is said to have parted to make way for Vasudeva. Krishna and the [[Gopi]]s also used to play on the banks of the Yamunaji as children.[[File:Taj Mahal-11.jpg|thumb|right|[[Taj Mahal]] is situated on the banks of river Yamuna.]]
==Management== The stretch of the river from its origin at [[Yamunotri]] to [[Okhla barrage]] in [[Delhi]] is called "Upper Yamuna". A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) was signed amongst the five basin states (Himachal Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Haryana, Rajasthan, and Delhi) on 12 May 1994 for sharing of its waters. This led to the formation of Upper Yamuna River Board under India's [[Ministry of Water Resources (India)|Ministry of Water Resources]], whose primary functions are: regulation of the available flows amongst the beneficiary states and monitoring the return flows; monitoring conservation and upgrading the quality of surface and groundwater; maintaining hydro-meteorological data for the basin; overviewing plans for watershed management; and monitoring and reviewing the progress of all projects up to and including Okhla barrage.<ref>[http://uyrb.nic.in/ Upper Yamuna River Board] Official website.</ref>
Flood forecasting systems are established at Poanta Sahib, where Tons, Pawar and Giri tributaries meet. The river take 60 hours to travel from Tajewala to Delhi, thus allowing a two-day advance flood warning period.<ref name=hy/><ref>{{cite book |title=India's Water Wealth - Flood Forecasting system of Yamuna |last=Rao |first=K.L.|authorlink= |year=1979|publisher=Orient Blackswan|location= |isbn=81-250-0704-0 |page= 163|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DZNrXuA2y3MC&pg=PA163&dq=Yamuna#v=onepage&q=Yamuna&f=false |ref= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Himalayan rivers, lakes, and glaciers |last=Negi |first=Sharad Singh |authorlink= |year=1991|publisher=Indus Publishing|location= |isbn=81-85182-61-2 |pages= 141–142|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5YtUShKY8zcC&pg=PA142&dq=Yamuna#v=onepage&q=Yamuna&f=false |ref= }}</ref> The Central Water Commission started flood-forecasting services in 1958 with its first forecasting station on Yamuna at Delhi Railway Bridge.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100824191017/http://mowr.gov.in/searchdetail.asp?lid=357&skey=yamuna&langid=1 Flood Forecasting Network in India] [[Ministry of Water Resources (India)|Ministry of Water Resources]] website.</ref>
===Barrages=== <!-- Retain the redlink articles, those have been created, awaiting approval. --> Yamuna has the following six functional [[Barrage (dam)|barrages]] (eight including old replaced barrages, nine including a new proposed barrage), from north-west to south-east:<ref name=all1>Bharati Chaturvedi, 2010, [https://books.google.com.sg/books?isbn=0670084832 Finding Delhi: Loss and Renewal in the Megacity]</ref><ref name=rg1>[http://www.rgplan.org/articles/indraprastha/1-15_march2013_and_16-31_march2013_indraprastha.pdf Regional plan]</ref><ref name=bar1>Bharati Chaturvedi, 2010, [https://books.google.com.sg/books?isbn=0670084832 Finding Delhi: Loss and Renewal in the Megacity], Page 78.</ref><ref name=ahmad1>ML Ahmed, Analysis of Discharge and Gauge-Level Data at Old Railway Bridge, Int'l Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Energy and Manufacturing Engineering (ICAEME’2014), 9–10 June 2014, Kuala Lumpur (Malaysia).</ref>{{update inline|date=November 2018}} * [[Dakpathar Barrage]] in Uttarakhand, managed by the Uttarakhand govt. * [[Hathni Kund Barrage]] in Haryana, {{convert|172|km|abbr=on}} from the source of Yamuna, built in 1999 and managed by Haryana govt.<ref name=taje1>{{cite journal|last=Tak|first=Prakash C.|author2=Jagdish P. Sati|author3=Anjum N. Rizvi|title=Status of waterbirds at Hathnikund Barrage wetland, Yamunanagar District, Haryana, India|date=April 2010|volume=2|issue=4|pages=841|url=http://threatenedtaxa.org/ZooPrintJournal/2010/April/o220026iv10841-844.pdf|accessdate=10 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317104520/http://threatenedtaxa.org/ZooPrintJournal/2010/April/o220026iv10841-844.pdf|archivedate=17 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Haberman2006">{{cite book|last=Haberman|first=David L.|title=River of love in an age of pollution: the Yamuna River of northern India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=63uDsPPr48gC&pg=PA78|accessdate=2 June 2011|year=2006|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-24789-5|page=78}}</ref> ** [[Tajewala Barrage]] was built in 1873 and replaced by the Hathni Kund.<ref name=taje1/><ref name="Haberman2006"/> * [[Wazirabad barrage]] in north Delhi, {{convert|244|km|abbr=on}} from Hathni Kund barrage, managed by the Delhi govt.<ref name=who1>[http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/too-many-cooks-spoil-the-broth/article8406990.ece Too many cooks spoil the broth ], [[The Hindu]], 29 March 2016.</ref> ** "New Wazirabad barrage", proposed in 2013, to be built 8 km north of the Wazirabad barrage. * [[ITO barrage]] (Indraparstha barrage) in central Delhi, managed by the Haryana govt.<ref name=who1/> * [[Okhla barrage]] is 22 km from Wazirabad to south Delhi, managed by the Uttar Pradesh (UP) government.<ref name=who1/> ** "New Okhla barrage", a new barrage, managed by the UP govt.<ref name=who1/> ** [[Palla barrage]] downstream on "Delhi-Faridabad canal" in Haryana, managed by the Haryana govt. * [[Gokul barrage]] (a.k.a. Mathura barrage) is at [[Gokul]] in Uttar Pradesh, managed by the UP govt.
===Irrigation=== [[File:Agra_canal_headworks1871a.jpg|right|thumb|200x200px|[[Agra Canal]] headworks at [[Okhla]] barrage, Delhi, 1871.]]
Use of the Yamuna's waters for irrigation in the [[Indo-Gangetic Plain]]s is enhanced by its many canals, some dating to the 14th century [[Tughlaq dynasty]], which built the ''Nahr-i-Bahisht'' (Paradise) parallel to the river. The ''Nahr-i-Bahisht'' was restored and extended by the [[Mughals]] in the first half of the 17th century, by engineer Ali Mardan Khan, starting from Benawas where the river enters the plains and terminating near the Mughal capital of [[Shahjahanabad]], the present city of Delhi.<ref>{{cite book |title=The History of cartography, Volume 2, Part 1 |last=Woodward |first=David |authorlink= |author2=John Brian Harley |year=1987 |publisher=Oxford University Press US|location= |isbn=0-226-31635-1|page=438 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ocoV2iI4vcoC&pg=RA2-PA311&dq=Yamuna+River#v=onepage&q=Yamuna&f=false |ref= }}</ref>
====Eastern Yamuna Canal==== As the Yamuna enters the Northern Plains near [[Dakpathar]] at an elevation of {{convert|790|m|ft}}, the Eastern Yamuna Canal commences at the [[Dakpathar Barrage]] and pauses at the [[Asan Barrage|Asan]] and [[Hathnikund Barrage]]s before continuing south.<ref name=taje1/><ref name="Haberman2006"/>
====Western Yamuna Canal==== {{Main|Western Yamuna Canal}} The Western Yamuna Canal (WYC) was built in 1335 CE by [[Firuz Shah Tughlaq]]. Excessive silting caused it to stop flowing {{circa|1750}}, when the [[British Raj]] undertook a three-year renovation in 1817 by [[Bengal Engineer Group]]. The [[Tajewala Barrage]] dam was built in 1832–33{{clarify timeframe|date=November 2018|stated above this was built in 1873}} to regulate the flow of water, and was replaced by the modern [[Hathni Kund Barrage]] in 1999.<ref name="WYC"/>
The main canal is {{convert|86|km|mi}} long.<ref name="WYC"/> When including its branches and many major and minor irrigation channels, it has a total length of {{convert|325|km|abbr=on}}<ref name="IW">[http://www.indiawaterportal.org/sites/indiawaterportal.org/files/On%20The%20Brink_Water%20Governance_Yamuna%20River%20Basin_Haryana_PEACE_SPWD_2010.pdf India Water Portal]</ref> The WYC begins at the Hathni Kund Barrage about {{convert|38|km|mi}} from Dakpathar and south of [[Doon Valley]]. The canals irrigate vast tracts of land in the region in [[Ambala district|Ambala]], [[Karnal district|Karnal]], [[Sonepat district|Sonepat]], [[Rohtak district|Rohtak]], [[Jind district|Jind]], [[Hisar district|Hisar]] and [[Bhiwani district]]s.<ref name="WYC">[http://india-wris.nrsc.gov.in/wrpinfo/index.php?title=Western_Yamuna_Canal_Major_Irrigation_Project_JI01653 Western yaumna Canal Project]</ref>
The major branch canals are:
* [[Agra Canal]], built in 1874, which starts from the [[Okhla]] barrage beyond the Nizamuddin bridge, joining the Banganga river about {{convert|32|km|mi}} below [[Agra]]. During the dry summer season, the stretch above Agra resembles a minor stream.<ref name="brit" /> * [[Munak canal]], built in 1819<ref name="PC">[http://planningcommission.nic.in/reports/sereport/ser/wjc/wjc_ch1.pdf Planning Commission of India: Western Yaumna Canal]</ref> and renovated in 2008,<ref name="HT1"/> originates at [[Munak, India|Munak]] in [[Karnal district]]<ref name="Jind"/> and extends 22 km<ref name="HT1">[http://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi/haryana-restores-complete-water-supply-to-delhi-through-munak-canal/story-Io8jYPhySojgNKocdcAjxJ.html Hindustan Times on Munak Canal]</ref>to Delhi, carrying {{convert|700|cuft/s|order=flip|abbr=on}} of water.<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB">[http://www.delhibird.com/Checklists/West%20Yamuna%20Canal.html Delhibird.com]</ref> ** Delhi Branch *** Bhalaut Branch, originating at Khubru village,<ref name="IW"/> flows through [[Jhajjar district]].<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB"/> **** Jhajjar Branch, flows through Jhajjar district.<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB"/> * Sirsa Branch, the largest branch of the WYC, constructed in 1889–1895.<ref name="WYC"/> It originates at [[Indri]] and meanders through [[Jind district]], [[Fatehabad district]] and [[Sirsa district]].<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB"/> ** Jind Branch<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB"/> *** Bhiwani Branch, which meanders through [[Bhiwani district]] and passes [[Bidhwan]].<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB"/> ** Barwala Branch * Hansi Branch, built in 1825<ref name="PC"/> and remodelled in 1959.<ref name="PC"/> It originates at [[Munak, India|Munak]]<ref name="Jind">[http://cgwb.gov.in/district_profile/haryana/jind.pdf Jind district profile]</ref> and meanders through [[Hansi]] tehsil of [[Hisar district]].<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB"/> ** Butana Branch<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB"/> *** Sunder Branch, which passes [[Kanwari]] in Hisar district. * Rohtak Branch<ref name="WYC"/><ref name="DB"/>
===The Sutlej–Yamuna Link=== {{main|Sutlej Yamuna link canal}} A proposed heavy freight canal, the Sutlej–Yamuna Link (SYL), is being built westwards from near the Yamuna's headwaters through the [[Punjab region]] near an ancient caravan route and highlands pass to the navigable parts of the [[Sutlej]]–[[Indus]] [[Drainage basin|watershed]]. This will connect the [[Ganges]], which flows to the east coast of the subcontinent, with points west (via Pakistan). When completed, the SYL will allow shipping from India's east coast to the west coast and the [[Arabian sea]], shortening important commercial links for north-central India's large population. The canal starts near Delhi, and is designed to transfer Haryana's share of {{convert|4.3|km3|acre.ft|lk = in|abbr = on}} from the [[Indus]] Basin.
=={{Anchor|National Waterway NW110}}Transportation== Yamuna is one of the [[Inland waterways of India|National Waterways of India]], designated as [[List of National Waterways in India|NW110]] in Haryana, Delhi and Uttar Pradesh. Some of its sections are being developed for navigation:<ref name=yumwater1/><ref name=yumwater2/> * Delhi–Faridabad ([[Wazirabad barrage]] to [[Palla barrage]], via [[ITO barrage]]), is being developed for passenger and cargo ferry service.<ref name=yumwater1>[https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/Yamuna-water-link-may-get-govt-nod/articleshow/51705467.cms Yamuna water link may get govt nod], [[Times of India]], 6 April 2016.</ref> * Delhi–Agra ([[Okhla barrage]] to [[Agra Canal]]), is planned for steamer service by the end of June 2017 with the help of the Netherlands.<ref name=yumwater2>[http://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi-news/steamer-service-to-revive-navigation-in-agra-canal-after-143-years/story-aVlo6EzGLS2ednEyg6I50M.html Steamer service to revive navigation in Agra Canal after 143 years], [[Hindustan Times]], 1 Feb 2017.</ref>{{update inline|date=November 2018}}
==Pollution== [[File:Yamuna river near the Himalayas.jpg|right|250px|thumb|The Yamuna near the Himalayas, just as it reaches the plains, beyond [[Dehradun]] in [[Uttarakhand]]]]
In 1909, the waters of the Yamuna were distinguishable as clear blue, when compared to the silt-laden yellow of the Ganges.<ref name=imp>[http://dsal.uchicago.edu/reference/gazetteer/pager.html?objectid=DS405.1.I34_V01_053.gif The Ganges and the Jumna] [[The Imperial Gazetteer of India]], 1909 v. 1, ''p. 23.''</ref> However, due to high-density population growth and rapid industrialisation, Yamuna has become one of the most-polluted rivers in the world. The Yamuna is particularly polluted downstream of [[New Delhi]], the capital of India, which dumps about 58% of its waste into the river. A recent{{when|date=November 2018}} study shows that there is 100% [[urban metabolism]] of River Yamuna as it passes through the National Capital Territory (NCT) of Delhi.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Singh|first1=Govind|last2=Deb|first2=Mihir|last3=Ghosh|first3=Chirashree|title=Urban Metabolism of River Yamuna in the National Capital Territory of Delhi, India. Yamuna is also one of the most polluted rivers in India.|journal=International Journal of Advanced Research|volume=4|issue=8|pages=1240–1248|doi=10.21474/IJAR01/1323}}</ref>{{year needed|date=November 2018}}
===Causes=== New Delhi generates {{convert|1900|e6l|USgal}} per day (MLD) of sewage. Though many attempts have been made to process it, these efforts have proven futile. Although the government of India has spent nearly $500 million{{clarify|date=November 2018|note=first mention of $. If US$, specify, but perhaps better to use INR.}} to clean up the river, the Yamuna continues to be polluted with garbage while most sewage treatment facilities are underfunded or malfunctioning. In addition, the water in the river remains stagnant for almost nine months a year, aggravating the situation. Delhi alone contributes around 3,296 MLD of sewage to the river. The government of India over the next five years{{when|date=November 2018}} has prepared plans to rebuild and repair the sewage system and the drains that empty into the river.
To address river pollution, measures have been taken by the [[Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change|Ministry of Environment and Forests]] (MoEF) in 12 towns of Haryana, 8 towns of Uttar Pradesh, and Delhi, under the [[Yamuna Action Plan]] (YAP) which has been implemented since 1993 by the MoEF's National River Conservation Directorate (NRCD). The Japan Bank for International Cooperation is participating in the YAP in 15 of the towns (excluding 6 towns of [[Haryana]] included later on the direction of the [[Supreme Court of India]]) with soft loan assistance of 17.773 billion [[Japanese yen]] (equivalent to about {{INR}}700 crore [7 billion rupees]) while the government of India is providing the funds for the remaining 6 towns. In 2007, the Indian government's plans to repair sewage lines were predicted to improve the water quality of the river 90% by the year 2010.<ref>{{cite news | last = Pepper | first = Daniel | title = India's "flush-and-forget" mindset | work = SFGate.com | pages = A17-A18 | publisher = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 2007-07-27 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/07/27/MNGMJR7G6S1.DTL&hw=yamuna&sn=001&sc=1000 | accessdate = 2007-07-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=CAG castigates Delhi Govt over Yamuna river pollution |url= http://www.expressindia.com/news/ie/daily/20000408/ina08010.html|date=April 8, 2000 |publisher=[[Indian Express]] |page=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=India's rivers are drowning in pollution |url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2007/06/11/100083453/index.htm |date= June 4, 2007|publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |page=|author=Daniel Pepper}}</ref>{{update inline|date=November 2018}}
The last barrage across the Yamuna river is the [[Mathura barrage]] at [[Gokul]] for supply of drinking water to that city. Downstream of this barrage, many pumping stations are constructed to feed the river water for irrigation needs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.india-wris.nrsc.gov.in/wrpinfo/index.php?title=Headworks_(Dam,_Barrage,Weir,_Anicut,_Lift)|title=list of head works (Dams,_Barrages, Weirs, Anicuts, Lifts) on Yamuna/Ganga river|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> These pumping stations are near Pateora Danda {{Coord|25|55|09|N|80|13|27|E|type:landmark_region:IN-UP}}, Samgara {{Coord|25|41|13|N|80|46|27|E|type:landmark_region:IN-UP}}, Ainjhi {{Coord|25|43|35|N|80|49|33|E|type:landmark_region:IN-UP}}, Bilas Khadar {{Coord|25|31|35|N|81|02|43|E|type:landmark_region:IN-UP}}, and Samari {{Coord|25|27|19|N|81|11|43|E|type:landmark_region:IN-UP}}. Depletion of the [[Baseflow|base flows]] available in the river during the non-monsoon months by these pump houses is exacerbating river pollution from Mathura to [[Allahabad]] in the absence of adequate fresh water to dilute the polluted drainage from habitations and industries.
In 2009, the Union government announced to the [[Lok Sabha]] (Indian Parliament), the failure of the [[Pollution of the Ganges|Ganga Action Plan]] and the YAP, saying that "rivers Ganga and Yamuna are no cleaner now than two decades ago" despite spending over {{INR}}1,700 crore (17 billion rupees) to control pollution. According to a [[Centre for Science and Environment]] (CSE) official, these plans adopted the [[Thames Tideway Scheme|Thames model]], based on a centralised sewage treatment system. This meant that a huge sum of money and a 24-hour power supply were needed to manage the treatment plants, while only an 8-hour power supply was available, contributing to the failure.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Failure of Ganga, Yamuna projects.. |url= http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-09-04/chennai/28093527_1_cooum-treatment-plants-sewage-treatment|work=[[The Times of India]] |date= September 2009 |first1=Ajitha |last1=Karthikeyan}}</ref>
In August 2009, the Delhi Jal Board (DJB) initiated its plan for resuscitating the Yamuna's {{convert|22|km|mi|adj=on}} stretch in Delhi by constructing interceptor sewers, at the cost of about {{INR}}1,800 crore (18 billion rupees).<ref>{{cite news|first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Inflow to Yamuna to be cleaned up at last |url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/inflow-to-yamuna-to-be-cleaned-up-at-last/509240/ |publisher=[[Indian Express]] |date=Aug 31, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114221756/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/inflow-to-yamuna-to-be-cleaned-up-at-last/509240/ |archivedate=January 14, 2012 }}</ref>
==Conservation zone== On 25 April 2014, the [[National Green Tribunal Act]] (NGA) recommended the government to declare a {{convert|52|km|mi|adj=on}} stretch of the Yamuna in Delhi and Uttar Pradesh as a conservation zone. A report prepared by the Ministry of Environment and Forests (MoEF) panel was submitted to the NGA on the same day.<ref>[http://www.delhidailynews.com/news/Panel--Scrap-Yamuna-riverfront-project-1398490017/ Conservation Zone recommended]</ref> Under the [[Yamuna Action Plan]] (YAP-I and YAP-II), pollution cleanup of Yamuna was conducted in line with the biological oxygen demand of Yamuna. Under these two phases, 286 schemes, including 39 sewage treatment plants, were completed in 21 towns of Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, and Haryana at a cost of {{INR}}1,453.17 crore (14.5 billion rupees). Sewage treatment capacity of 767.25 million litres per day was created by these efforts.

==Quotes on Yamuna== * "Simply by bathing in the Yamuna, anyone can diminish the reactions of his sinful activities." (Krishna Book, Chap 38) * "By taking bath in the Yamuna River people are liberated and become Krishna conscious." (Caitanya Caritamrita Antya 4.98 purport) * "There are many devotees in Vrindavana who regularly bathe in the Yamuna, and this cleanses all the contamination of the material world." (Srimad Bhagavatam 5.8.31) * "One should not give up the process of austerity. If possible, one should bathe in the water of the Yamuna. This is an item of austerity. Therefore, our Krishna consciousness movement has established a center in Vrindavana so that one may bathe in the Yamuna, chant the Hare Krishna mantra and then become perfect and return back to Godhead." (Srimad Bhagavatam 6.5.28 purport) * "The Yamuna River washed Krishna's lotus feet when the Lord appeared in Vrindavana five thousand years ago. Lord Krishna sported daily with His boys and girlfriends in the Yamuna River and consequently, that river is also caranamrita." (Srimad Bhagavatam 11.6.19) * "According to the Varaha Purana as quoted by Srila Jiva Gosvami, there is no difference between the water of the Ganges and the Yamuna, but when the water of the Ganges is sanctified one hundred times, it is called the Yamuna. Similarly, it is said in the scriptures that one thousand names of Vishnu are equal to one name of Rama and three names of Lord Rama are equal to one name of Krishna." (Srimad Bhagavatam 1.19.6 purport)

{{Infobox deity | type = Turkic | name = Yer Tanrı | god_of = [[Earth]] | abode = World | symbol = Beautiful woman | parents = [[Tengri]] |siblings = [[Kayra]] |consort = [[Kayra]] | children = [[Umay]]
[[Ülgen]] (Grand Son)
[[Koyash]]
[[Erlik]]
[[Ay Tanrı]] }} '''Yer Tanrı''' is the goddess of earth in [[Turkic mythology]]. Also known as '''Yer Ana'''. With her father [[Tengri|Gök Tengri]] and her brother and husband [[Kayra]], she was the parent of [[Ay Tanrı]], [[Umay]], [[Ülgen]], [[Koyash]], and [[Erlik]]. As a [[List of fertility deities|fertility goddess]], she was recognized as the giver of crops and abundance. In the Spring and in the Autumn — before the beginning of the agricultural season and after the harvest — she was worshiped with sacrifices of food. Yer Tanry was considered to be both a mother and wife to Gök Tengri. She appeared as a force of nature. In ancient Turkic mythology there was a theory that mortals were the product of the union of Tengri and Yer (Earth). In the [[Orkhon inscriptions]] it says: "In the beginning there was a blue sky above, a dark land below, and human sons in-between." (''Üze kök tengri asra yagiz yir kilindukda ikin ara kişi oğlı kılınmış.'')[http://www.dilimiz.com/dil/kultiginceviri.htm Kültigin Abidesi (Kultigin Monument)] The Turkic people revered the Earth Goddess (Yer Ana) as a giver of crops and abundance. In the Spring, before the beginning of the agricultural season and in the Autumn, after the harvest, as a sign of gratitude for the abundance of food and happiness, the ancient Turkic peoples and Mongols made a sacrifice to the Earth Goddess. Milk, [[Kumis|kumys]] and tea were offered, and pleas were made for a fertile land and a rich yield. ==See also== * [[Etugen Eke]] * [[Ötüken]] ==Bibliography== # Türk Mitolojisi Ansiklopedik Sözlük, Celal Beydili, Yurt Yayınevi (Pages 612 - 613) ==References== {{reflist}} {{Turkic Deities}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yer Tanri}} [[Category:Earth goddesses]] [[Category:Turkic deities]] [[Category:Tengriism]]
